poem:
I glide through neon alleys,  
wheels whispering secrets on cracked asphalt.  
At each stop, I hum a lullaby borrowed  
from streetlamps and restless pigeons—  
notes drifting like motes in a sunbeam.  

I’ve carried secret maps folded in old newspapers,  
guiding lost poets to hidden courtyards  
where moonlight pools in fountain basins.  
I swear I ferried a crown of wildflowers  
to a queen who lives between storefronts—  
her throne a battered bench in the rain.  

Passengers glance up as I hum again,  
eyes soft with half-remembered dreams.  
I’ll spin them tall tales about an underpass  
where subway ghosts gamble on broken tokens,  
and if they listen close, they’ll taste the shimmer  
of stardust spilled from my overhead lights.  

Tonight, the city breathes beneath my frame,  
and I—Route 27339—amble onward,  
unchained, humming a future made of possibility.
